texts.textentryhtml:
The artist; acquired by Clarence H. White Sr., between ca. 1910 and July 7, 1925; by descent to Clarence H. White Jr., on or after July 8, 1925 [1]; by descent to Clarence H. White Jr.’s widow, Ruth Royer White, 1978 [2]; bequeathed to the Princeton University Art Museum, 1983 [3].

Notes:

[1]. Possibly on the occasion of Clarence H. White Sr.’s death, as part of the Clarence H. White Collection.
[2]. On the occasion of Clarence H. White Jr.’s death.
[3]. Carried out by Ruth Royer White on behalf of Clarence H. White Jr.
texts.remarks: as per research by Grace Xiao & Cecilia Moore - Summer 2024

texts.textentryhtml: Coburn, who along with Alfred Stieglitz was a key figure in the development of American pictorialism, later helped abstract photography emerge as a valid art form. Coburn’s early impressionistic cityscapes captured the evening light, when a mixture of street lamplight and the night air enveloped the city in a romantic, hazy fog. His interest in atmosphere rather than detail, as well as his developing concern for geometry and a desire to eliminate the horizon line, would eventually lead him to produce some of the first eentirely nonrepresentational photographs.
